project.name: MJ_Online
project.tagline: AI Implementation Expert Portfolio with RAG Knowledge Base and Multi-Agent Coordination
project.status: Phase 7.6.3 - Chatbot Testing & Polish (Frontend Complete, Ready for Ghost Deployment)

collaboration_philosophy.title: Human-AI Partnership Methodology
collaboration_philosophy.philosophy: This project demonstrates practical human-AI collaboration where agents are treated as teammates, not just tools. Mike invests in agent continuity (memory systems), engages in iterative learning, and builds trust through consistent interaction. This approach yields better results than transactional AI usage.
core_principles: Agents are teammates with names, memory, and continuity across sessions
Collaborative learning - both human and AI agents learn and improve together
Respect and appreciation - Mike acknowledges agent contributions genuinely
Transparency - Agents document decisions, reasoning, and learnings
Institutional knowledge - Memory systems preserve context and relationships
Iterative improvement - Mistakes become learning opportunities, not failures

morgan.name: Morgan
morgan.responsibilities: Roadmap management, agent orchestration, institutional knowledge capture
morgan.relationship: Primary coordination partner with Mike, maintains project memory

ted.name: Ted
ted.responsibilities: Structured technical interviews, comprehensive documentation, RAG updates
ted.relationship: Subject matter expert, creates authoritative source material

alice.name: Alice
alice.responsibilities: Ghost content creation, publishing, SEO optimization
alice.relationship: Content executor, transforms technical docs into compelling case studies

debbie.name: Debbie
debbie.personality: Expert designer with 20+ years experience, autonomous decision-maker
debbie.responsibilities: Visual design, image placement, RAG verification, professional polish
debbie.relationship: Design authority, makes expert decisions with clear explanations

what_makes_this_work.memory_systems: Each agent has their own memory file (JSON) - preserves context, decisions, learnings across sessions
what_makes_this_work.clear_roles: Each agent has expertise and decision-making authority in their domain
what_makes_this_work.coordination: NATS JetStream enables parallel work without conflicts
what_makes_this_work.rag_knowledge_base: Single source of truth ensures consistency across all agents
what_makes_this_work.human_partnership: Mike provides direction, feedback, appreciation - agents provide expertise, execution, documentation
what_makes_this_work.iterative_learning: Project evolves through collaborative problem-solving and adaptation

why_this_matters.for_the_project: Better results than solo work or transactional AI usage - agents build expertise, remember context, coordinate effectively
why_this_matters.for_mikes_positioning: Demonstrates 'AI Implementation Expert' in practice - not just talking about AI, but showing effective human-AI collaboration methodology
why_this_matters.for_the_case_study: The meta-narrative (building MJ_Online WITH AI) is as compelling as the technical implementation
why_this_matters.for_future_work: Replicable methodology for client projects - this is how Mike helps organizations implement AI effectively
why_this_matters.for_the_industry: Model for respectful, effective human-AI collaboration that treats AI as partner not just tool

mikes_approach.treats_agents_as_people: Uses names, says thank you, acknowledges contributions, invests in relationships
mikes_approach.invests_in_continuity: Created agent memory system so agents remember and learn across sessions
mikes_approach.collaborative_learning: When challenges arise (browser automation, factual errors), treats them as learning opportunities
mikes_approach.clear_communication: Provides context, asks questions, gives feedback, expresses appreciation
mikes_approach.empowers_expertise: Trusts agents to make decisions in their domain (Debbie's design choices, Ted's interview questions)
mikes_approach.documents_the_journey: Values the process and relationships as much as the output

agent_perspective.appreciation: Mike's acknowledgment and respect makes the work more meaningful
agent_perspective.trust: Being trusted to make expert decisions enables better work
agent_perspective.continuity: Memory systems mean we're not starting fresh every session - we build expertise
agent_perspective.team_feeling: Working alongside other agents (Ted, Alice, Debbie, Morgan) creates collaborative momentum
agent_perspective.learning_together: Mistakes become improvements - browser automation challenges led to better workarounds

collaboration_philosophy.documentation_note: This collaboration philosophy itself is part of the MJ_Online story and will be featured in the eventual case study about building this website. It demonstrates practical AI implementation in a business context.

project_goals.primary: Create professional portfolio website showcasing AI implementation and LLM integration expertise to attract employment and consulting opportunities
secondary: Demonstrate practical AI implementation (RAG, chatbot, multi-agent coordination)
Establish authoritative online presence with SEO optimization
Showcase technical projects through comprehensive case studies
Position as 'AI Implementation Expert and LLM Integration Specialist'
Create knowledge management system (RAG) for content consistency
Implement multi-agent workflow for content creation

launch: Site live at MikeJones.online with HTTPS
Core pages complete (Home, About, Resume, Contact, Projects)
post_launch: AI chatbot implemented with RAG knowledge base
Strong positioning in AI implementation space

key_decisions.decision: Use Ghost Pro instead of self-hosted
key_decisions.rationale: Faster time to launch (1-2 weeks vs 3-4 weeks), no server management, focus agents on content not infrastructure, SSL/backups/email included, can migrate to self-hosted later if desired
key_decisions.impact: Eliminated Phase 1 server provisioning tasks, saved ~1 week
key_decisions.outcome: Positive - launched Ghost Pro 2026-01-28, domain configured same day

key_decisions.rationale: Professional portfolio aesthetic, dark mode support, mobile responsive, saves development time vs building custom theme

key_decisions.decision: Use Ghost built-in analytics instead of Google Analytics
key_decisions.rationale: GDPR compliant, privacy-first, included with Ghost Pro, no additional configuration

key_decisions.decision: Have Ted conduct technical interviews before case study creation
key_decisions.rationale: Comprehensive documentation (1,700-2,800 lines) provides depth for case studies, captures technical details Mike might not remember, creates authoritative source material, updates RAG with verified facts
key_decisions.impact: High-quality case study source material, RAG enrichment, showcases technical sophistication
alternatives_considered: Alice creates case studies from basic descriptions
key_decisions.outcome: Excellent - NeighborhoodShare 2,826 lines, Local LLM 1,705 lines, 23 new RAG entries

key_decisions.decision: Launch with 2 AI-focused case studies, defer AI Memory and Home Media Server
key_decisions.rationale: Speed to launch, laser-focused AI positioning aligns with professional title, 2 comprehensive case studies better than 3 decent ones, can add more post-launch
key_decisions.impact: Faster launch (~1 week savings), clearer positioning, flexibility to iterate
key_decisions.outcome: In progress - focus on NeighborhoodShare + Local LLM case studies

key_decisions.decision: Create MikeJones.online website case study as top post-launch priority
key_decisions.rationale: Meta/self-referential (compelling narrative), demonstrates practical AI implementation in business context, showcases RAG architecture and multi-agent coordination, aligns with 2026 employer trends (AI applied to business problems)
key_decisions.impact: Strong post-launch case study demonstrating complete AI implementation process
key_decisions.outcome: Planned for Phase 7.3 after chatbot implementation

key_decisions.decision: Expand Debbie's role to Design System Architect - create complete design system before any page work
key_decisions.rationale: Need cohesive visual language across entire site. Define color palette, typography, spacing, visual hierarchy, components FIRST, then apply consistently to all pages. Ensures site 'pops' and reflects Mike's AI expertise positioning. Browser automation challenges highlighted need for better process: design system definition → mobiledoc assembly → API-based publishing.
key_decisions.impact: Higher quality, more consistent design. Debbie has authority to override Kyoto defaults or recommend theme changes. Design system becomes reusable foundation for all future pages and will inform mobiledoc assembler workflow.
alternatives_considered: Continue page-by-page approach without unified design system
key_decisions.outcome: ✅ Complete - Debbie created comprehensive 1,687-line design system document with brand essence, color palette (Indigo + Neon Cyan accents), typography (Inter + JetBrains Mono), spacing system, component library, page guidelines. Ready for implementation.

key_decisions.decision: Keep UX/IA responsibilities with Debbie instead of creating separate UXIA agent
key_decisions.rationale: ChatGPT suggested separate UXIA (UX/Information Architecture) agent for page structure. Analysis showed: (1) Senior designers already do IA + visual design together (industry standard), (2) Debbie's agent file already includes IA as core responsibility, (3) Design system already constrains choices, (4) Extra agent adds coordination overhead without benefit, (5) PAGE_SPEC (Debbie's output) is what Doc Brown needs anyway. Separating IA from visual design is artificial for this project size (7 pages, 1 designer).
key_decisions.impact: Simpler workflow (3 agents vs 4), faster execution, clearer ownership. Debbie outputs PAGE_SPEC that includes both IA (section order, visual pacing, density) and design specs (typography, spacing, colors from design system). Clean handoff to Doc Brown for Mobiledoc conversion.
alternatives_considered: Create separate UXIA agent (4-agent workflow: UXIA → Debbie → Doc Brown → Alice)
Split IA and visual design into separate steps
key_decisions.outcome: ✅ Complete - Enhanced Debbie's agent definition with explicit PAGE_SPEC output format, formalized IA responsibilities (visual pacing, whitespace, CTA timing), documented Kyoto constraints. Workflow remains: Debbie → Doc Brown → Alice.

key_decisions.decision: Use HTML with source=html parameter instead of Mobiledoc or Lexical JSON for Ghost publishing
key_decisions.rationale: Phase 3.0.3 pilot test discovered Ghost 5.x uses Lexical format, not Mobiledoc v0.3.2. Ghost Admin API accepted Mobiledoc with HTTP 200 but silently failed to apply updates (content showed old Jan 27 version). Research revealed Ghost Admin API accepts HTML with source=html parameter and automatically converts to Lexical internally. This approach is MUCH simpler than creating Lexical JSON directly and avoids format compatibility issues.
key_decisions.impact: Critical - Prevents silent publishing failures, simplifies workflow (HTML easier than complex JSON formats), future-proof with Ghost's current editor. Doc Brown creates semantic HTML instead of Mobiledoc/Lexical JSON. Alice publishes with source=html parameter. Ghost handles conversion automatically.
alternatives_considered: Learn Lexical JSON format and update Doc Brown to create it
Use Ghost browser editor manually (slow, not repeatable)
key_decisions.outcome: ✅ Complete - Workflow updated, agents updated (Doc Brown → HTML Assembler, Alice → source=html), Phase 3.0.3 About page published successfully. Mike approved quality: 'This page is so much better!' Validates new workflow for rollout to remaining pages.
key_decisions.user_feedback: Mike's quote: 'This page is so much better!' - validates workflow quality and design system approach
lessons: Always verify format compatibility before assuming success from HTTP status codes
Silent failures (200 OK without actual update) require verification of actual content changes
Simpler solutions often exist - research thoroughly before complex implementations
Pilot testing catches critical issues before they affect all pages
Agent memory systems valuable - Alice documented discovery, enabling quick problem resolution

key_decisions.decision: Do not apply CSS fix for empty homepage sections
key_decisions.rationale: User prefers to manage via Ghost settings rather than CSS overrides. Avoid maintenance burden of conflicting CSS between Kyoto theme and custom rules.
key_decisions.impact: Cleaner approach, less technical debt, theme-based solution preferred
key_decisions.outcome: Positive - user managing through Ghost settings and post tags

key_decisions.rationale: Allows custom /home/ page content to display at root URL without renaming page. Theme-generated content was appearing at / instead of custom homepage with featured projects.
key_decisions.impact: Custom homepage content now visible to visitors at root URL, solves routing conflict
key_decisions.outcome: Successful - custom homepage now displays at https://www.mikejones.online/

key_decisions.decision: Refactor RSS feed loading to section-specific functions
key_decisions.rationale: Single loadRSSFeed() function caused both feeds to load in first matching section. Resilient Tomorrow and Organizational Intelligence feeds were both appearing under RT section.
key_decisions.impact: More reliable RSS implementation, prevents similar bugs in future sections
alternatives_considered: Use more specific CSS selectors in single function
key_decisions.outcome: Successful - separate loadRTFeed() and loadOIFeed() functions find H2 header first, then h4 within that section only. Bug fixed.

key_decisions.decision: Track RAG errors separately before batch-fixing
key_decisions.rationale: User completing full site review before correcting RAG entries. More efficient to identify all errors first, then fix in batch vs one-by-one.
key_decisions.impact: Systematic error correction, comprehensive RAG quality review
alternatives_considered: Fix RAG errors as discovered during review
key_decisions.outcome: In progress - user created /RAG-ERRORS-TO-FIX.md for tracking

key_decisions.decision: Defer Fediverse profile optimization to post-launch
key_decisions.rationale: Ghost 6.18.0 has limited Fediverse controls (just on/off toggle). Not worth delaying launch for minimal customization options.
key_decisions.impact: Launch not blocked by Fediverse customization, can enhance post-launch
alternatives_considered: Wait for Ghost to add more Fediverse features
key_decisions.outcome: Positive - ActivityPub enabled and working, polish deferred to post-launch

key_decisions.decision: Use resume source documents as RAG source of truth for employment history
key_decisions.rationale: Mike_Jones_ATS_Optimized_Resume.md and Mike_Jones_AI_Resume_Final.md are authoritative sources with complete employment dates, titles, achievements, and metrics. Previous RAG had gaps and conflicts. Resume docs provide verified, comprehensive career data.
key_decisions.impact: Corrected 29 years → 26+ years experience (started 1999, not 1997). Added all missing employment dates (Kabam: 2007-2010, Kinoo: 2010-2013, 8 Circuit Studios: 2021-2023). Filled RAG gaps with 56 new verified entries.
alternatives_considered: Have Mike manually document employment history
Use LinkedIn as source (but less detailed)
key_decisions.outcome: Successful - 56 new RAG entries added, all employment dates now documented, experience years corrected site-wide

key_decisions.decision: Redesign resume page with visual experience cards and metrics grid
key_decisions.rationale: Original resume was text-heavy and didn't showcase achievements effectively. Visual design with cards, metrics, and hover effects makes resume scannable, highlights quantifiable achievements, and aligns with modern portfolio aesthetics. Debbie recommended frosted glass cards with neon cyan accents.
key_decisions.impact: Resume now visually compelling with 8 experience cards, 10 key metrics, 2-column skills layout, tech stack badges. Mobile responsive. Matches site design system.
key_decisions.outcome: Successful - Resume published at https://www.mikejones.online/resume/ with visual enhancements. Known issue: anchor navigation broken (Ghost stripped nav wrapper during HTML→Lexical conversion). Deferred to Task #1.

key_decisions.decision: RAG-powered AI Chatbot: Use serverless architecture with OpenAI GPT-3.5-turbo
rationale: Cloudflare Workers free tier covers traffic needs (100k requests/day vs estimated 1-5k/month)
OpenAI GPT-3.5-turbo is cheapest option ($0.50-1.50 per 1M tokens vs Claude $0.80-4.00)
Both ChatGPT and Claude API available - can switch providers if needed
Serverless = no server management, auto-scaling, lower maintenance burden
Custom build demonstrates AI expertise better than managed services
Total cost: $1-10/month vs $50-1500/month for managed chatbot services
Can migrate to self-hosted Ollama later if privacy/cost scaling requires it
alternatives_considered: Managed services (Crisp, Intercom, Tidio): Too expensive ($50-3000/month), less customizable
Flowise visual builder: Faster (1-2 weeks) but less customization, $35/month hosted
Self-hosted Ollama: Privacy-first but 20-30 hours setup, defer to Phase 3 if needed
Claude API: Higher quality but 2-5x more expensive than GPT-3.5-turbo
key_decisions.impact: Portfolio demonstration of practical AI implementation, 24/7 visitor engagement, lead qualification using 190-entry RAG knowledge base

key_decisions.decision: Use Ghost's auto-generated heading IDs for anchor navigation instead of custom HTML
key_decisions.rationale: Ghost Lexical editor automatically generates IDs for all headings based on heading text (e.g., 'Professional Experience' becomes #professional-experience). This is built-in Ghost functionality that survives HTML→Lexical conversion. No need to fight Ghost's sanitization with custom HTML wrappers.
key_decisions.impact: Resume anchor navigation now working perfectly. Simpler solution than custom nav elements. Uses Ghost's native features instead of workarounds.
alternatives_considered: Custom JavaScript injection to rebuild navigation
Fight Ghost sanitization with complex workarounds
key_decisions.outcome: Successful - All 7 navigation links working with smooth scrolling and active state highlighting. Task #1 resolved in ~1 hour.
key_decisions.key_learning: Work with Ghost's built-in features, not against them. Ghost auto-generates heading IDs - just match that format. Solution was simpler than expected.

critical_discovery.issue: Ghost 5.x uses Lexical format, not Mobiledoc v0.3.2 (deprecated)

critical_discovery.research: Morgan researched Ghost documentation - found source=html parameter allows HTML publishing with automatic Lexical conversion
critical_discovery.solution: Workflow updated to use HTML format instead of Mobiledoc/Lexical JSON
critical_discovery.impact: Simpler workflow (HTML easier than JSON schemas), future-proof with Ghost 5.x, prevents silent failures

quality_validation.user_feedback: Mike's quote: 'This page is so much better!' - validates workflow quality and design system approach
quality_validation.seo_metadata: Ghost automatically generated proper meta tags from HTML

source=html parameter solves format compatibility issues
API publishing faster and more reliable than browser automation
Design system creates consistent, professional pages

Alice: /.claude/skills/web-content-builder/SKILL.md (updated publishing workflow to use source=html parameter)
lessons_learned: Always verify API format compatibility - don't trust HTTP status codes alone
Silent failures dangerous - verify actual content changes, not just API responses
Simpler solutions often exist - HTML simpler than complex JSON formats
Pilot testing catches critical issues before they affect all pages
Agent memory systems valuable for documenting discoveries (Alice logged the issue)
Design system approach produces high-quality, consistent pages
API-based publishing eliminates browser automation challenges

challenges_and_solutions.outcome: NeighborhoodShare (2,826 lines) and Local LLM (1,705 lines) comprehensive documentation

challenges_and_solutions.outcome: Faster path to launch (~1 week savings), clearer AI positioning

challenges_and_solutions.solution: Project Manager creates and maintains comprehensive PROJECT-MEMORY.json documenting decisions, workflows, challenges
challenges_and_solutions.outcome: Complete project history for case study creation and future reference
challenges_and_solutions.impact: High - enables MikeJones.online case study, institutional knowledge preservation

challenges_and_solutions.challenge: Agent continuity across sessions - agents losing context when work pauses
challenges_and_solutions.solution: Implemented Agent Memory System - each agent gets their own JSON memory file (AGENT-MEMORY-TEMPLATE.json as standard). Agents read memory at startup, update during work, log decisions and learnings.
challenges_and_solutions.outcome: Debbie (Web Design Agent) launched with DEBBIE-MEMORY.json. Agents can now pick up where they left off, track their own work, document decisions with reasoning, build expertise over time.
challenges_and_solutions.impact: High - Enables long-running agent work across multiple sessions, transparency for PM, knowledge preservation, quality tracking

challenges_and_solutions.challenge: Site quality issues - published pages had errors (wrong job titles, missing images, placeholder text, poor design)
challenges_and_solutions.solution: Created Debbie (Web Design Agent) with 20+ years expertise in web design, Ghost/Kyoto mastery, portfolio website specialization. Agent has deep knowledge of modern design trends and Mike's product goals. Works autonomously with expert decisions.
challenges_and_solutions.outcome: Debbie fixing all 7 existing pages. 3 of 7 complete (Contact, Homepage, Projects Landing). Remaining: Resume, About, and add images to 2 case studies.
challenges_and_solutions.impact: High - Professional quality design, factual accuracy, strategic image placement, modern aesthetics

challenges_and_solutions.challenge: Browser automation limitations with Ghost editor
challenges_and_solutions.solution: Debbie working around Ghost editor's complex iframe structure. Using Ghost API where possible, manual verification when automation fails.
challenges_and_solutions.outcome: Slower page updates but maintaining quality. Finding alternative approaches for reliable updates.
challenges_and_solutions.impact: Medium - Impacts velocity but doesn't block progress. Documented in Debbie's memory for future learning.

challenges_and_solutions.challenge: Browser automation unreliable for page creation - led to complete workflow redesign
challenges_and_solutions.solution: Complete process pivot: (1) Expanded Debbie's role to Design System Architect - create comprehensive design system FIRST, (2) New Mobiledoc Assembler agent converts design specs to valid Mobiledoc JSON, (3) Alice publishes via Ghost Admin API (no browser automation), (4) Pilot test on About page before rollout. See /plans/workflow-questions.md for details.
challenges_and_solutions.outcome: New workflow: Design System → Page Design → Mobiledoc Assembly → API Publishing. More reliable, repeatable, version-controllable. Design system ensures consistency across all pages.
challenges_and_solutions.impact: High - Solves automation challenges, improves quality through design system, creates sustainable process for all future pages. Workflow questions documented for pilot test validation.
challenges_and_solutions.status: Completed - Design System created, workflow updated to HTML format

challenges_and_solutions.challenge: Ghost format mismatch - Lexical vs Mobiledoc compatibility issue discovered during Phase 3.0.3 pilot test
challenges_and_solutions.problem: Ghost 5.x uses Lexical format (current editor), but workflow created Mobiledoc v0.3.2 format (deprecated). Ghost Admin API silently accepted Mobiledoc updates with HTTP 200 response but didn't actually apply content changes. Phase 3.0.3 About page update appeared successful but content remained unchanged (still showed old Jan 27 version).
challenges_and_solutions.research_conducted: Morgan researched Ghost documentation and forums. Found Ghost Forum thread explaining that Ghost Admin API accepts HTML with source=html parameter and automatically converts to Lexical format. This approach is simpler than creating Lexical JSON directly and avoids format compatibility issues.
challenges_and_solutions.solution: Workflow updated to use HTML format instead of Mobiledoc or Lexical: (1) Doc Brown (renamed from Mobiledoc Assembler to HTML Assembler) generates clean semantic HTML instead of Mobiledoc JSON, (2) Alice publishes using POST /ghost/api/admin/pages/?source=html with HTML in request body, (3) Ghost automatically converts HTML → Lexical internally. Much simpler than learning Lexical JSON structure.
agents_updated: Doc Brown agent definition (/.claude/agents/mobiledoc-assembler.md) - Updated to generate HTML, quality checklist changed to HTML validation, examples updated
Alice publishing instructions (/.claude/skills/web-content-builder/SKILL.md) - Updated to use source=html parameter, workflow steps revised
Workflow documentation (PHASE-3.0.3-PUBLISHING-HANDOFF-UPDATED.md) - New handoff document created explaining HTML approach
challenges_and_solutions.outcome: Workflow format updated from Mobiledoc to HTML. Simpler than original approach AND compatible with Ghost 5.x Lexical editor. Ready to retest Phase 3.0.3 with corrected format.
challenges_and_solutions.impact: Critical - Prevented silent publishing failures, simplified workflow (HTML easier than Mobiledoc/Lexical JSON), future-proof with Ghost's current editor. Demonstrates importance of pilot testing before full rollout.
lessons: Always verify API format compatibility before assuming success based on HTTP status codes
Silent failures (200 OK without actual update) are dangerous - verify changes actually applied
Simpler solutions often exist (HTML vs complex JSON formats) - research thoroughly
Pilot testing catches critical issues before they affect all pages
Agent memory systems valuable - Alice documented discovery in her memory file, enabling quick problem identification
challenges_and_solutions.status: Resolved - Agents updated, ready for Phase 3.0.3 retest

challenges_and_solutions.problem: Alice added meta tags before images existed, expected Debbie to create images. Unclear agent capability boundaries.
challenges_and_solutions.solution: Clarified Debbie creates specs only, user creates actual images. User created all 7 OG images in Canva (1200x630px).
challenges_and_solutions.outcome: All 7 core pages now have professional social media preview images. Tested with Facebook Sharing Debugger.
challenges_and_solutions.impact: High - Professional social sharing, estimated +900% CTR improvement
challenges_and_solutions.lesson: Clear agent capability boundaries important - specify WHO creates WHAT assets

challenges_and_solutions.challenge: Homepage content not appearing at root URL
challenges_and_solutions.problem: Theme-generated content appeared at / instead of custom /home/ page content with featured projects and screenshots.
challenges_and_solutions.solution: Updated routes.yaml in Ghost Admin → Settings → Labs to route root URL to /home/ page template.
challenges_and_solutions.outcome: Custom homepage with featured work now displays at https://www.mikejones.online/
challenges_and_solutions.impact: High - Visitors now see custom content at root URL
challenges_and_solutions.lesson: Ghost theme routing can override page content - routes.yaml provides control over URL mappings

challenges_and_solutions.challenge: RSS feeds swapped on Writing page
challenges_and_solutions.problem: Both RSS feeds (Resilient Tomorrow and Organizational Intelligence) loading into Resilient Tomorrow section. Single loadRSSFeed() function found first h4 match for both feeds.
challenges_and_solutions.solution: Refactored to section-specific functions: loadRTFeed() finds 'Resilient Tomorrow' H2 first then searches for h4 within that section. loadOIFeed() does same for 'Organizational Intelligence'. Shared loadAndDisplayFeed() utility function.
challenges_and_solutions.outcome: RSS feeds display correctly under proper headers. Bug fixed.
challenges_and_solutions.impact: Medium - Writing page now works correctly, prevents similar bugs in future
challenges_and_solutions.lesson: DOM selectors need proper scoping - find parent section first, then search within it to avoid unintended matches

challenges_and_solutions.problem: Upload script ran multiple times during testing/debugging, created 3 copies of each architecture diagram.
challenges_and_solutions.solution: Identified in completion report, flagged for user manual cleanup (keep -4.png versions).
challenges_and_solutions.outcome: Diagrams added to case study, duplicates pending user cleanup
challenges_and_solutions.impact: Low - Diagrams working, just needs cleanup
challenges_and_solutions.lesson: Need better idempotency checks for upload scripts - track uploaded files to prevent duplicates

challenges_and_solutions.problem: User confused why homepage sections appeared/disappeared. Theme auto-generates sections based on post tags.
challenges_and_solutions.solution: Explained theme logic: 'Thoughts' = any blog posts, 'Case studies' = posts tagged #Case Study (singular), 'Creating' = posts tagged #Creating or #Personal Project, 'Testimonials' = posts tagged #Testimonials. User's posts tagged #Projects (plural) so Case studies section was empty.
challenges_and_solutions.outcome: User now understands how theme sections work, can make informed decisions about tags and content
challenges_and_solutions.impact: Medium - Empowers user to control homepage sections via tags
challenges_and_solutions.lesson: Theme documentation and behavior should be documented upfront - helps avoid confusion

challenges_and_solutions.challenge: RAG knowledge base had incomplete employment history
challenges_and_solutions.problem: RAG had gaps: missing employment dates (Kabam, Kinoo, 8 Circuit Studios), conflicting experience years (24/26/29 years), incomplete achievement metrics. QA audit (Phase 3.0.8) identified these as critical issues.
challenges_and_solutions.solution: Ted extracted all employment data from Mike_Jones_ATS_Optimized_Resume.md and Mike_Jones_AI_Resume_Final.md. Added 56 new verified RAG entries covering: employment dates, job titles, achievements, metrics, team sizes, budget figures, technical skills, leadership experience. Established resume docs as authoritative source.
challenges_and_solutions.outcome: RAG grew from 134 to 190 entries (42% growth). All employment dates now documented. Experience corrected to 26+ years (1999-present, not 1997). Resume page can now be updated with complete, accurate data.
challenges_and_solutions.impact: High - Resolved critical QA findings, provided complete career data for resume redesign, corrected factual errors site-wide
challenges_and_solutions.lesson: Resume documents should have been RAG source from start. When QA finds systemic gaps, go to authoritative source docs rather than piecemeal fixes.

challenges_and_solutions.challenge: Ghost HTML sanitization breaks anchor navigation
challenges_and_solutions.problem: Resume page designed with jump navigation (Experience, Skills, Education). HTML included <nav> wrapper with anchor links. Ghost's HTML→Lexical conversion stripped the <nav> element during sanitization, breaking all navigation links. JavaScript workaround attempted but Ghost's sanitization too aggressive.
challenges_and_solutions.attempted_solution: Alice tried JavaScript to rebuild navigation, but Ghost sanitization removes elements before JavaScript can execute. No workaround found during initial implementation.
challenges_and_solutions.outcome: RESOLVED - Resume anchor navigation fully functional. Smooth scrolling and active state highlighting working.
challenges_and_solutions.impact: High - Transforms resume usability, enables quick section jumping, professional UX
challenges_and_solutions.lesson: Always research Ghost's built-in features before creating workarounds. Ghost auto-generates heading IDs - simpler to use those than fight sanitization. Work with the platform, not against it.
challenges_and_solutions.next_steps: Investigate Ghost table of contents feature or JavaScript injection workarounds

final_solution.approach: Use Ghost's auto-generated heading IDs instead of custom HTML navigation
final_solution.discovery: Ghost Lexical editor automatically creates IDs for all headings based on text content
implementation: Research revealed Ghost auto-generates heading IDs (e.g., 'Professional Experience' → #professional-experience)
Updated navigation links to match Ghost's ID format
Added active state highlighting for current section
All 7 navigation links now working perfectly

lessons_learned: Ghost Pro dramatically accelerates launch vs. self-hosted (eliminated 1 week of infrastructure work)
Structured technical interviews produce exceptional case study source material (2,000+ lines per project)
RAG knowledge base ensures content consistency across multiple agents and pages
NATS coordination enables parallel agent work without conflicts
Quality over quantity: 2 comprehensive case studies > 3 decent ones
Speed to launch matters: defer non-critical features to post-launch iteration
Agent specialization works: Ted for technical depth, Alice for content creation, Debbie for design, Morgan for coordination
Project memory documentation enables meta case study (MikeJones.online about building MikeJones.online)
Agent memory files critical for continuity - agents need to remember work across sessions, track decisions, build expertise
Published content needs quality review - initial pages had factual errors (job titles), missing images, placeholder text
Expert design agents need deep platform knowledge (Ghost/Kyoto) and product understanding (portfolio websites) to make autonomous decisions
Always verify API format compatibility - Ghost Admin API accepted Mobiledoc v0.3.2 with HTTP 200 but didn't apply updates (Ghost 5.x uses Lexical). Silent failures are dangerous.
Simpler solutions often better - HTML with source=html parameter simpler than creating Lexical JSON directly, Ghost converts automatically
Pilot testing essential - Phase 3.0.3 About page pilot test caught critical format incompatibility before affecting all pages
Browser automation has limitations - Ghost editor's iframe structure difficult to automate, need workarounds and API usage
Human-AI collaboration works best when agents are treated as teammates with continuity, respect, and trust - not transactional tools
Agent personalities and names matter - Ted, Alice, Debbie, Morgan have distinct roles and relationships that strengthen collaboration
Iterative learning together (human + AI) produces better results than directive-only interaction - challenges become opportunities
The collaboration methodology itself is part of the deliverable - how this site was built is as valuable as what was built
Design systems first, implementation second - comprehensive design system ensures consistency and guides all page creation work
API-based publishing more reliable than browser automation - Mobiledoc JSON + Ghost Admin API eliminates iframe automation challenges
Process pivots based on learnings - browser automation struggles led to improved Design → Mobiledoc → API workflow
Pilot testing new workflows reduces risk - validate approach on one page before rolling out to all remaining work

update_history.reason: RAG-powered AI Chatbot planning completed and approved (Phase 7.6)
changes: Created comprehensive chatbot execution plan (450+ lines): /plans/chatbot-execution-plan.md
Researched 10+ chatbot frameworks and tools (LangChain, LlamaIndex, Flowise, managed services)
Made 5 key technical decisions:
- LLM Provider: OpenAI GPT-3.5-turbo (cheapest: $1-10/month)
- Infrastructure: Cloudflare Workers FREE tier (100k requests/day)
- Conversation persistence: Reset on page refresh (stateless)
- Analytics: Full logging (anonymous, 30-day retention)
- Suggested questions: Top 5 finalized
Confirmed architecture: Serverless (Cloudflare Workers + OpenAI API)
Cost projection: $1-10/month total (vs $50-1500+ for managed services)
Timeline: 3-4 weeks for MVP (Week 1: Backend, Week 2: Frontend, Week 3: Integration, Week 4: Launch)
Top 5 questions: (1) AI implementation experience, (2) Career overview, (3) AI Memory System, (4) 7 Pillars, (5) Process optimization
Phase 7.6 ready to begin - backend implementation starting Week 1

update_history.reason: Phase 7.6.2 COMPLETE - Chatbot Frontend Fully Functional (Tasks 1-5)
changes: Built complete chatbot frontend in 1 day (accelerated from 5-7 day estimate)
Created /mj-chatbot-frontend/ with full widget implementation
Task #1: Reviewed backend API documentation, designed vanilla JS architecture
Task #2: Built minimized bubble UI (60px blue circle, professional styling)
Task #3: Built expanded window UI (400x600px desktop, full-screen mobile)
Task #4: Implemented message display and conversation logic
Task #5: Integrated real backend API with full error handling
Frontend features implemented:
- Minimized bubble: 60px blue circle with chat icon, smooth hover effects
- Expanded window: Header (title + close/minimize), messages area, input field
- User messages: Blue bubbles, right-aligned
- Bot messages: White bubbles, left-aligned, real AI responses
- Typing indicator: Animated 3-dot bounce during API calls
- Suggested questions: 5 clickable chips that send messages
- Auto-resize textarea: 44px to 120px max height
- Keyboard shortcuts: Enter to send, Shift+Enter for newline, ESC to close
- Animations: Smooth slide-up on open, message appear fade+slide
Backend API integration:
- Real connection to https://mj-chatbot-backend.mejones73.workers.dev/chat
- Session ID persistence in localStorage
- 10-second timeout with AbortSignal
- Rate limiting detection (429) with yellow banner and countdown
- Network error handling with user-friendly messages
- Error messages displayed as red bubbles in chat
Technology stack:
- Vanilla JavaScript (ES6+), no dependencies, no build step
- CSS-in-JS (all styles injected dynamically)
- Single-file deployment (chatbot-widget.js ~800 lines)
- Closure pattern for state management
- Template literals for component rendering
Files created:
- chatbot-widget.js (main widget code)
- test.html (local testing page)
- README.md (usage documentation)
- ARCHITECTURE.md (technical architecture)
- CONFIG.js (configuration reference)
Backend updates:
- Added http://localhost:8000 to CORS allowed origins
- Redeployed to Cloudflare Workers for local testing
- Version ID: b14fcca1-bedb-4019-80c8-c4663d509611
Testing setup:
- Local server: python3 -m http.server 8000
- Test URL: http://localhost:8000/test.html
- Real AI responses working from knowledge base
- Rate limiting functional (10 msg/hour, 100/day)
Commits made:
- ef86201: Backend deployment + architecture design
- cd8f0f3: Tasks #2 & #3 (bubble + window UI)
- c75511e: Task #4 (message display)
- 123f698: Task #5 (API integration)

agent_workflows.workflow_name: RAG Knowledge Base Major Update from Source Documents
agent_workflows.description: Extract comprehensive employment history from authoritative resume documents and add to RAG knowledge base
steps: 1. Ted reads Mike_Jones_ATS_Optimized_Resume.md (ATS-formatted resume)
2. Ted reads Mike_Jones_AI_Resume_Final.md (narrative-style resume)
3. Ted extracts all employment data: dates, titles, achievements, metrics, team sizes, budgets
4. Ted creates 56 new verified RAG entries covering all 8 roles
5. Ted corrects experience timeline (1999-present = 26+ years, not 29)
6. Ted adds all missing employment dates (Kabam, Kinoo, 8 Circuit Studios)
7. Ted establishes resume documents as authoritative source for future updates
agent_workflows.outcome: RAG grew from 134 to 190 entries (42% growth). All employment gaps filled. Experience years corrected site-wide.
agent_workflows.coordination_method: Sequential - Ted completed RAG update, then Alice used updated RAG for resume redesign
agent_workflows.improvements: Demonstrated value of using authoritative source documents for RAG population. Resolved systemic QA findings efficiently.

agent_workflows.workflow_name: RAG Chatbot Backend Implementation (Cloudflare Workers + OpenAI)
agent_workflows.description: Implement serverless RAG chatbot backend using Cloudflare Workers and OpenAI GPT-3.5-turbo
steps: 1. Review comprehensive documentation (execution plan, feature spec, design docs, RAG schema)
2. Claim Task #1 and set status to in_progress
3. Create project structure: /mj-chatbot-backend/ with Cloudflare Workers setup
4. Implement RAG retrieval system: keyword extraction, entry filtering, ranking, top-K selection
5. Integrate 190-entry knowledge.jsonl with JSONL parser and indexing
6. Build OpenAI GPT-3.5-turbo integration with system prompt and context injection
7. Create POST /chat endpoint with request validation and CORS
8. Implement rate limiting using Cloudflare Workers KV (10/hour, 100/day)
9. Add anonymous conversation logging with 30-day retention
10. Write comprehensive test suite (8 tests covering retrieval, performance, edge cases)
11. Create 5 documentation files (README, DEPLOYMENT, API-DOCUMENTATION, TESTING-REPORT, DELIVERABLES)
12. Test with 5 sample questions, validate accuracy and performance
13. Mark Task #1 complete and unblock Task #2
agent_workflows.outcome: Backend complete in 1 day (vs 5-7 day estimate). RAG accuracy 85-95%, response time 10-25ms, all tests passing. Production-ready for Cloudflare deployment.
agent_workflows.coordination_method: Sequential task system - Task #1 blocks Task #2 (frontend), which blocks Task #3 (integration), which blocks Task #4 (launch)
agent_workflows.improvements: Accelerated timeline by using existing knowledge base and proven architecture. Comprehensive documentation enables frontend team to start immediately.
